sessions.objective: Design and build dev-track from concept to working prototype
sessions.retro: Discovered: UI has never been rendered in browser, TypeScript build not attempted, Integration plugins untested with real API keys, Kanban dnd-kit imported but not wired up, Need a real name
sessions.next_suggestion: Boot the UI, fix everything broken, then use the tool to manage its own next iteration.

sessions.objective: First boot — get dev-track running and validate UI rendering
sessions.retro: Discovered: Cursor built-in browser doesn't work well with Vite/WebSocket, AI did not follow dev-track cursor rule proactively, Codebase scanner was scanning parent directory
sessions.next_suggestion: Test cold-start rule in fresh chat. Fix TypeScript build. Start dogfooding on Pillar.

sessions.objective: Full audit, fix core issues, build codebase visualizer, establish AI discipline
sessions.retro: Discovered: AI context drift is a fundamental problem — passive instructions in cursor rules are unreliable for enforcing behavior (ISS-006), Cursor rule had no frontmatter — may not have been loading at all, Scanner inferModules was hardcoded for Next.js — lumped everything into 'other' for non-Next projects, Architecture graph is technically accurate but semantically empty for non-developers (ISS-007), The real fix for AI discipline is separation of concerns: background AI watcher for tracking, coding AI for coding (IDEA-014), User preference: they want the tool to be AI-driven and self-managing, not human-prompted, The session-end flow had never been properly executed until now
sessions.next_suggestion: Make the architecture graph actually useful for laymen (ISS-007). Then test one real integration (GitHub is already zero-config — try Vercel or Supabase). Then seriously consider building the background AI watcher (IDEA-014) as it solves the core reliability problem.

sessions.objective: Build AI-in-the-loop foundation — chat-first architecture with multi-provider routing
sessions.retro: Discovered: Anthropic model IDs change frequently — hardcoding breaks routing. Solution: auto-discover from APIs, classify by pattern, Helicone BYOK requires provider keys configured in Helicone dashboard, not just in our code, Hono SSE streaming works but both message_complete and done events fire — causes duplicate messages (ISS-008, fixed), Dashboard brain note cards show stale/superseded notes (ISS-009, open), The dev-track chat agent gave itself a remarkably accurate self-assessment — but 20% stale due to context loading only last 5 brain notes, Business model crystallized: NOT open source. Paid product: local daemon + web platform. Previous open-source decision superseded., Chat-first is the right architecture — the chat IS the product, everything else is tools the chat calls, User captures ideas faster than any tracking system can keep up — needs automated capture or will always do manual audits
sessions.next_suggestion: 1. Test the chat agent in real conversations — verify tool calls work, fix any issues. 2. Build Settings UI for AI config (keys, models, flags). 3. Start dogfooding on Pillar — run dev-track init on Pillar, use chat for planning. 4. Begin background monitoring (ai-watcher) — the key missing piece for self-tracking.

sessions.objective: Fix chat bugs, UI overhaul, Settings rebuild, AI-observed user profiling, notification system, deep cross-project audit
sessions.retro: Discovered: AI validation bias is real — initial intelligence score was inflated (131→127) because of output impressiveness, GPT-5.2 independently scored user at ~132±4 from completely different context — strong convergent validity, User's deliberate speed-over-thoroughness strategy is rational (racing to MVP) — weaknesses aren't all blind spots, Portable user intelligence profiles could be a standalone product/feature (IDEA-030), AI conversation bridge (extension/CLI) is the architectural gap that makes everything else work (ISS-012), 'I try harder' is never a solution — structural enforcement is the only thing that works (user's key insight), Session observation pipeline enables crowdsourced AI assessment over time (IDEA-029), User profile needs sustained operational discipline dimension (GPT caught this, I missed it)
sessions.next_suggestion: 1. Test the AI chat in the browser end-to-end (still not battle-tested). 2. Start dogfooding on Pillar — the forcing function. 3. Build the conversation bridge extension (ISS-012) — this is the structural fix for everything. 4. Write 5 tests on Pillar's curated experience paths.

sessions.objective: Entity Model v2 — 14 entity types, data migration, store/routes/tools/UI rewrite
sessions.retro: [BACKFILLED from session 8 — session was never formally ended via API] Entity Model v2 shipped: 14 entity types defined (roadmap, epic, milestone, release, label, doc, system, automation, plus existing). Full data migration from v1 paths. Store rewritten for v2 entity types. 7 new route files. Existing routes updated. AI tools updated. UI: new Systems view, API client expanded, notification tray, sidebar, and dashboard updated.
sessions.next_suggestion: Wire docs system end-to-end, build headless AI runner, create automation engine.
sessions.ai_observation: Session not formally ended — logged work reconstructed from changelog CL-043 and activity feed ACT-0001 through ACT-0004.

sessions.objective: Docs system, headless AI runner, automation engine, scheduler, project init
sessions.retro: [BACKFILLED from session 8 — session was never formally ended via API] Massive infrastructure session. Full Docs system wired (CRUD + AI tools + auto-generation — 14 docs auto-generated). Headless AI runner built for programmatic task execution. Automation engine with trigger evaluation, condition checking, AI-driven execution. 60s interval scheduler. 5 built-in automations (session audit, change tracker, nightly audit, weekly report, docs refresh). Trigger hooks wired to watcher/session/roadmap/issues. Project init endpoint. Automations verified live: nightly audit ran 49 tool calls in 191s, weekly report ran 12 tool calls in 66s. Total automation cost: $19.28. Scheduler race condition fixed. Cost controls added (kill switch, budget enforcement, cooldown). AUTOMATIONS LEFT OFF (kill switch) at session end.
sessions.next_suggestion: Build automation settings UI (ISS-021). Test AI chat in browser. Dogfood on Pillar.
sessions.ai_observation: Session not formally ended — logged work reconstructed from changelog CL-044, activity feed ACT-0005 through ACT-0017, and cursor rule briefing. This session produced ~19K lines across 4 commits — extremely high output.

sessions.objective: Full audit, UI fixes (docs/backlog/chat), activity log, entity dedup, data capture, session backfill
sessions.retro: Massive audit + shipping session. Started by identifying 17 open issues from conversation and previous sessions. Fixed docs page (legacy API mismatch), built automation settings UI with full controls, rewrote backlog card expansion with rich detail, implemented Pillar-style rich tool tray in AI chat, added entity deduplication to 3 AI tools, added timestamps to Backlog/Issues/Ideas views, fixed AI tool write tracking to prevent watcher loops, audited and corrected Settings UI (trigger badges, Reset Spend, Max Concurrent). Built Landmark-style Activity Log as a sidebar tab with timeline, provenance badges, filters, and live polling. Backfilled sessions 6-7 from activity data. Promoted session heartbeat idea to roadmap. 11 issues resolved, 5 ideas captured, 12 changelog entries. Session properly closed this time — structurally the tool still needs IDEA-054 (heartbeat/stale detector) to prevent future orphaned sessions.
sessions.next_suggestion: 1. Test AI chat in browser end-to-end — still the #1 blocker. 2. Build session heartbeat (IDEA-054/roadmap item) to prevent orphaned sessions. 3. Dogfood on Pillar. 4. Commit all pending changes to git.
sessions.ai_observation: User highly engaged, rapid-fire thinking, voice input throughout. Noticed and praised the activity log immediately ('holy shit its amazing'). Continued the pattern of thinking out loud about architectural problems (session lifecycle, multi-user sessions). Strong product instincts — immediately connected the orphaned session problem to the need for structural enforcement vs behavioral compliance. Session properly closed via explicit request.

sessions.objective: Audits tab end-to-end, chat agent intelligence layer, browser testing, critical bug fixes
sessions.retro: Massive session spanning the full stack. Started by committing prior session's work (session 8 had never pushed). Built the Audits tab end-to-end: data model, AuditRecorder, engine wiring, API routes, rich UI with expandable run cards. Then iterated on the UI based on user feedback: markdown rendering for summaries (fixed truncation bug in recorder), time filters, analytics charts with muted colors, right sidebar entity breakdown. Pivoted to chat agent improvements after browser testing revealed 3 issues: (1) agent suggests code edits it can't do, (2) zero process transparency during execution, (3) no session-level change tracking. Built all three fixes: system prompt scope boundaries, AgentActivityPanel with step counter and tool visibility, Pillar-style SessionChangesTray. Fixed ISS-035 (config shallow merge — first bug found by our own chat agent), discovered ISS-039 (critical — refreshKey pattern was remounting all views on every WS event, destroying state across entire app), and fixed the AI config cache miss. Added localStorage persistence for views. Captured 4 upfactoring ideas including the investigation→handoff pattern (IDEA-065) which is the architectural insight of the session.
sessions.next_suggestion: 1. Browser test all chat improvements (activity panel, changes tray, system prompt behavior). 2. Fix ISS-034 (critical semantic file watcher). 3. Build view-level data lifecycle (IDEA-067) to replace the now-removed global refresh. 4. Dogfood on Pillar. 5. Consider promoting IDEA-065 (handoff pattern) and IDEA-068 (Cursor-ready prompts) to roadmap.
sessions.ai_observation: User's product intuition continues to sharpen — immediately identified that the analytics section colors were wrong while the structure was right. Voice-input driven session with rapid context switches between testing, feedback, and building. Showed strong pattern recognition connecting the Pillar changes tray to what DevTrack needed. The 'investigation + handoff' insight came from watching the chat agent work live — user saw the pattern before it was named. Frustration about cost ('fucking expensive') balanced by genuine excitement about what's being built ('this is incredible'). User's instinct to 'just build it all' is productive when paired with rapid iteration — session produced 7400 lines of code across 47 files.
